questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Take turns reading Nahum 1 aloud together.
tips: Read slowly and clearly
Pause if something strikes you

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, summarize what this passage is about.
tips: Keep it brief
Capture the main flow

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What stood out to you the most? What's the 'best bit'?
tips: Share what personally resonated
Listen to your partner

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What is the main point or central message of this passage?
tips: Think about the author's intent
Look for the big idea

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What difficulties or questions do you have about this passage?
tips: It's okay not to understand everything
Share honestly

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: What will you do about it? How will you apply this to your life?
tips: Be specific and practical
Think about this week

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about what you've learned and your applications.
tips: Thank God for what you learned
Pray for each other

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Nahum 2:1-10 aloud, focusing on the vivid imagery of the city's destruction.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'plunder' (v. 3, 5, 7) in the context of the city's destruction
Pay attention to the emotional tone: from warning (v. 1) to despair (v. 10)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO God is judging, WHAT happens to Nineveh, WHERE the judgment occurs, and WHY God is acting.
tips: The Assyrian empire (Nineveh) is destroyed
The city is plundered and left desolate
This judgment is a response to Nineveh's oppression of God's people

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the chariots racing (v. 4), the river gates opening (v. 6), or the city being 'like a pool whose waters run away' (v. 10)?
tips: The chariots racing through the streets (v. 4) shows the speed and chaos of the attack
The city becoming 'a pool whose waters run away' (v. 10) is a powerful metaphor for total desolation
The desperate plea 'Halt! Halt!' (v. 3) but no one turning back (v. 4) highlights the city's helplessness

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Nahum trying to communicate to Judah through this passage?
tips: Nahum is telling Judah that God will judge the proud and powerful (Nineveh) because they have oppressed God's people
This shows that God's kingdom is not of this world and the mighty will fall
Judah should take heart because God is restoring His people (Jacob and Israel)

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The imagery of the city's destruction, the role of the 'scatterer', or the connection to Judah's current situation?
tips: 'Scatterer' (v. 1) refers to the forces that bring destruction, but in the context, it's God's judgment
Nineveh was the capital of the Assyrian empire, which had been a threat to Judah
The 'river gates' (v. 6) are a specific city gate in Nineveh that opens to allow the army in

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of God's judgment on the proud to your life this week?
tips: Reflect on times when you've been proud and how God's judgment might be coming
Pray for humility when you feel secure in your success
Share the lesson with someone who is arrogant

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His judgment on the proud and ask for His protection for Judah.
tips: Thank God for the truth that the proud will fall
Ask for courage to be humble in the face of adversity
Pray for the city of Nineveh to be desolate and for Judah to be restored

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Nahum 3:1-10 aloud, paying attention to the emotional tone of God's judgment and the repeated phrase 'woe' (vv. 1, 2).
tips: Notice the repetition of 'woe' as a sign of severe judgment
Pay attention to the phrase 'deadly charms' (v. 3) which describes Nineveh's deceitful nature
The phrase 'no easing hurt' (v. 5) conveys the permanence of the wound

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO God is judging, WHAT He declares (the judgment on Nineveh), WHERE this judgment falls (the city of Nineveh), and WHY (because of its wickedness and deceit).
tips: Include the comparison to Thebes (v. 9) which became an exile
Note that the Assyrian shepherds are asleep (v. 10) showing their lack of awareness of coming judgment
The city is described as a 'prostitute' (v. 3) who betrays nations with lies

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the description of Nineveh as a 'bloody city' (v. 1), the 'deadly charms' (v. 3), or the 'wound that is grievous and no easing' (v. 5).
tips: The phrase 'bloody city' (v. 1) evokes the violence and sin of Nineveh
The image of the 'deadly charms' (v. 3) shows how Nineveh uses deceit to attract nations
The description of the wound that has no healing (v. 5) is a powerful metaphor for the futility of Assyrian power

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Nahum trying to communicate to Judah about God's judgment on Nineveh and the hope for those who are righteous?
tips: Nahum warns Judah that Assyrian power will be destroyed, just as Thebes was exiled
The message is that God's judgment is just and will come to all who are wicked, but He offers healing to those who turn to Him
This passage shows that God's mercy is for the faithful, as seen in the Christ connection

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are confusing? The use of 'prostitute' for Nineveh, the comparison of Assyrian fortresses to fig trees, and the concept of 'no easing hurt'.
tips: In ancient Near Eastern context, cities were sometimes described as 'prostitutes' for their deceitful alliances (vv. 3-4)
The fig tree metaphor (v. 10) means that the Assyrian fortresses are unstable and will fall quickly, just as figs that are ripe fall from the tree
'No easing hurt' (v. 5) means the wound is deep and will not heal naturally, but God's healing comes through Christ

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of 'no easing hurt' to a situation where you feel grievous wounds that seem without healing this week?
tips: Consider an area where you feel a deep spiritual wound that isn't healing (e.g., past hurt, sin, relationship issues)
Remember that Christ is the healer of grievous wounds (as per the Christ connection)
Pray for God to provide healing when you feel your wounds are without end

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray about the theme of grievous wounds that require healing through Christ.
tips: Thank God for being the healer of our deepest wounds
Ask for the courage to trust Christ when we feel our wounds are without healing
Pray that the Assyrian empire's destruction (like our own failures) is replaced by Christ's healing
